To disable compensation system, push and hold "reset" button until  red light goes off.   Enabling the compensation system should result in noticeable decrease  in amplitude of output on the oscilloscope (reduce speed of trace to  ~1sec per division to see movement).   When control unit loses power, must instruct unit to apply low pass filter to prevent feedback, as follows:   COM2 from PC is connected to RS232 input on control unit through a null modem cable   Start TERMINAL. Choose settings-> communications. Select COM2, 19200 baud, 8 bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.   Hit "return" or "escape" on terminal a few times to get main menu.   Hit "0" to enter system menu   Choose diagnostic menu   Choose custom filter design   Hit "0" to select an axis/stage   Select stage 6   Hit "1" to select filter type   Choose LPF10   Hit "2" to select parameter 1   Enter 20 for this parameter   Hit 6 to update all axes, answer "y" to update all                                                                                        NYU Langone Medical Center       Student Login       Library                 Policies & Disclaimers

To disable compensation system, push and hold "reset" button until  red light goes off.   Enabling the compensation system should result in noticeable decrease  in amplitude of output on the oscilloscope (reduce speed of trace to  ~1sec per division to see movement).   When control unit loses power, must instruct unit to apply low pass filter to prevent feedback, as follows:   COM2 from PC is connected to RS232 input on control unit through a null modem cable   Start TERMINAL. Choose settings-> communications. Select COM2, 19200 baud, 8 bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.   Hit "return" or "escape" on terminal a few times to get main menu.   Hit "0" to enter system menu   Choose diagnostic menu   Choose custom filter design   Hit "0" to select an axis/stage   Select stage 6   Hit "1" to select filter type   Choose LPF10   Hit "2" to select parameter 1   Enter 20 for this parameter   Hit 6 to update all axes, answer "y" to update all                                                                                        NYU Langone Medical Center       Student Login       Library                 Policies & Disclaimers

In The Next Room or The Vibrator Play: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content          < back        In The Next Room or The Vibrator Play   Event Date and Time: January 29, 2014 – February 3, 2014 January 29th - January 31st at 8pm, Saturday, February 1st at 2pm & 8pm, Sunday February 2nd at 8pm and February 3, 2014 at 8:00pm Location: Atlas Theatre 111 2nd Ave, 3rd floor New York, NY 10003 As the technological innovations of the 20th Century are about to dawn, one woman discovers the key to sexual satisfaction and personal freedom. A Tony-nominated play by one of America's most acclaimed writers, In The Next Room re-defines the notion of what an hysterical romp can be. $15 general admission, $10 students/seniors Tickets available through www.smarttix.com starting Wednesday November 6. Vocal Vibration ← Rest of You                                                                                                  Rest of You             Spring 2014                                                   Syllabus   Illusion   Listening   Talking   E-Unconscious   Rest of Us                                              « Why I fear……… the dots? Here I come to know what.       The Why »                              Vocal Vibration                           5 Feb 2014 | Why                            +++      + + +   e n e r g y   + + +        +++  v i b r a t i o n  +++      +++  b i o f e e d b a c k  +++   ~   A C T :: O B S E R V E :: R E A C T :: T R A N S F O R M   ~   Mind / Body / Spirit   Thought / Matter / Aether   Breath / Heartbeat / Blood Flow   +++   Chakra / Chi / Aura / Aether   Stillness / Thought / Movement / Breath   Mindfulness / Meditation / Reflection / Reaction   +++   Frequency / Rate / Speed / Velocity   Gravity / Levity / Inertia / Stasis   Flow / Movement / Evolution / Change   +++   Vibration / Resonation / Oscillation / Scintillation   Variation / Alternation / Vacillation / Fluctuation   Mutability / Changeability / Alterability / Vicissitude   +++   Resound / Pulsate / Reverberate / Echo   Waver / Quiver / Shiver / Shake   Move / Wander / Travel / Traverse   +++   c o n c e p t  ::  a live performance of classical indian vocal music accompanied by the real-time visualization, sonification, and materialization of vibration produced in the body during singing.   :: hear the sound :: see the energy :: feel the vibration ::     +  witness the physical properties of sound + body   +  experiment with ways we can listen with our bodies   +  study at the intersection of~   // music :; wellness // science :; religion // myth :; truth //   +  develop an awareness of  vibration in the body during vocalization   +  explore how pitch and vowel move vibration to different parts of the body   +  consider the relationship between vibration in the body and~   // chakras // nadis // the subtle body //   +  study spiritual practice and  secular relevance   +  see, hear, and feel sound and observe the physiology of vocalization     +++   Click the image to watch the  vocal vibration  prototype :      http://vimeo.com/81439607   +++   I’m inspired by the  visualization  /  sonification  /  materialization  potential of this project and the consideration of listening with your body.  Last semester in Automata I experimented with the pitch of an actuator.  The frequency of a vibrating object like a solenoid or a vibration motor creates an audible pitch that correlates to the note at that frequency – the vibration alert of your phone is a note and when it’s sitting a resonant surface it’s even more audible.  It’s an interesting consideration to transmit this physical pitch data between bodies by mapping the frequency of a tonal audio signal to the frequency of the actuators.  The ability to both hear and feel the pitch of a tonal vocalization in unison.   Tonal actualization. Pitch sensing.  Resonance exchange.  Sympathetic vibration.   In a recent conversation I learned an interesting distinction between western and indian singing techniques. European opera and most western vocal technique involves singing from the diaphragm with a vertical concentration of air movement.  Indian vocal practices emphasize the lateral movement of the chest and lungs – a horizontal concentration of air movement. The difference between directing breath across your length versus your width.  The expansion of the chest would be an interesting thing to incorporate into the visualization with a tension sensor.   In addition to vibration throughout the body, what else can we learn about the body from a real-time visualization:: posture / air movement / muscle tension in the face, throat, chest, and abdomen / facial contortion / the expansion of the chest / the vibration of the vocal chords (phonation).  What are the complexities involved in the physical act of singing and how does it relate to the cognitive influence of pitch, melody, and modes?  And how does the time-space of sound in music influence the mind?     ~         +++T o p i c s       Flow   Beauty   Vibration   Concentration   Vividness   Happiness   Ecstasy   Polarity   Equanimity   Wellness   Meditation   Vedic Health   Vibrational Healing   The Intention of Song   The Sound of the Body   The Physiology of Speech and Hearing   Sympathetic Vibration   Nadis and The Subtle Body   Listening with Your Body   Speech Pathology   Phonation   Touch   Entelechy and Energeia   The Philosophy of Mind   Dualism   Hinduism   Buddhism   Toaism         +++C o n s i d e r a t i o n s   // What is energy?   // What is happiness?   // Who is the rest of you?   // What parts of the body do we listen with besides the sound input of our ears?   // What energies are activated through the practice of concentration?   // What are the effective energies of wellness?     +  neuro chemistry: the effects of the bodies natural healing hormones: endorphins, adrenaline, norepinepherine, seratonin, dopamine, oxytosin, neuro-peptides.  How these have effects on the immune system, T cells, the brain, calm and happiness.   +  how laughter and smiling effect the production of these hormones and healing energy   +  empathy, compassion, giving, volunteering all change energy   +  power, chi, chakras, subtle bodies, meridians, reiki, energy work   +  meditation, focused concentration, changing alpha, beta, delta waves   +  the power of touch   +  intuition, psychic vibrations   +  positive affirmations, reframing, acknowledgement, active listening   +  sound, music and the effect on energy, mood, healing   +  kirtan chanting         +++A p p l i c a t i o n s       the transmission of vibration from a vocalists body to another body.   the amplification of vibration in a vocalist’s own body as a biofeedback mechanism.   the prepared voice:: pluralization from a singular action.       +++S e n s o r s  &  M o t o r s       http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piezoelectric_sensor   http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromyography   http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroencephalography   http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eccentric_(mechanism)       /\/\/\/                                                                     Leave a Reply Cancel Reply            You must be logged in to post a comment.                                   « Why I fear……… the dots?
